There was another possible way of dealing with leaks or hotspots inside the cooling passages of a regeneratively cooled engine: Mix some kind of additive into the fuel which would decompose at high temperatures to deposit a solid, insulating material. This only really works when you have a liquid hydrocarbon fuel, since the additives are liquids too. This has been done using tetraethyl orthosilicate, which is a liquid silicate ester which dissolves in hydrocarbons. Another option is silicone oil, which has been tested the same way but with rockets using ethanol or methanol as their fuel.
In both cases the silicon-containing additive decomposes at any leaks or hotspots to form silicon dioxide, which either plugs the leak, or locally increases the thickness at a hotspot, effectively curing it. Of course the resulting silicon dioxide itself can get ablated away by the heat, but since there is always a small percentage of the precursor additive in the fuel, it is continually re-deposited for as long as the engine is running and fuel is flowing.
This only takes a couple of percent by weight of the silicon-containing additive in the fuel, most of which burns perfectly happily along with the fuel, so the engine performance is not significantly reduced. This is no good for tactical missile applications since the rocket exhaust will contain some silicon dioxide smoke, producing a persistent, trackable exhaust trail. But for rockets fired into space (or fired once in space), this doesn't matter.

13:20 "...[fluid] always flows from high to low [pressure]". This is not true - break down the terms in the Navier-Stokes equations and you will see that momentum plays a part. A fluid with momentum will continue flowing in the same sense until a pressure gradient accelerates it. For a period of time then, fluid with existing momentum will flow from low to high pressure, before changing direction.
The "folk physics" phrase has found itself into textbooks. It even had the smart guy at "Tech Ingredients" (who has a lot to say about fluid flow and dynamics) absolutely convinced that the folk physics phrase was a law of nature.

Dear Mr. Dodd. Thank you for yet another excellent, informative, and interesting video.

You mention that certain forms of cooling, such as film cooling, cannot be used on a spinning turbine. This is not entirely correct. Jet engine turbines commonly use film cooling. Cooler air is taken from previous stages and run inside the (usually) ceramic turbine blades, allowing it to bleed out of tiny holes. The high-pressure turbine is the hottest part of the engine. "Cooler" is a relative term here, as this air is well hotter than 1000 degrees C.

An excellent source for jet engine knowledge is Rolls-Royce's iconic book "The Jet Engine", first published in 1955, and updated many times since then. I highly recommend it, if nothing else for the superb illustrations. Jet engines are not rocket engines, but they do share many traits.

Please keep up the good work!

Sutton, Rocket Propulsion Elements 9th Edition, Chapter 8).

This isn't specifically related but some concepts are very similar. The regenerative cooling works because the oxygen concentration is insufficient inside the nozzle walls to worry about. Many diesel engines ignite diesel fuel in 300 - 500 psi of compressed atmospheric air that is above the flash point of diesel fuel in the cylinder chamber whilst the injection pump that is injecting the fuel compresses it to 20,000 psi. There isn't a worry of ignition even though the fuel is compressed and hot because there is insufficient oxygen present to ignite it while it's traveling to the cylinder chamber, I think regenerative cooling follows similar physics

Another factor that isn't usually appreciated when talking about propellant choice is prospective propellants' properties as they relate to regenerative cooling. Such as whether or not the coolant is chemically stable at elevated temperature. Hydrogen for instance is stable at elevated temperatures, meaning it won't break down into something other than hydrogen. Hydrazine on the other hand is not, and will break down into something other than hydrazine by the time it gets to the injectors. Of course temperature and pressure effect this question greatly. Another pair of factors are the volumetric heat capacity and conductivity of the propellant/coolant. Of course they have to be effective enough to keep temperatures in check, but there's actually more to it than just "Good enough".

The F-1 burns about 2.5 tons of propellant a second. A substantial portion of that must be pumped through all of those tiny tubes that are brazed together to form the body of the motor. The turbopumps already have the monstrous job of stepping up the pressure of the propellants high enough that they will flow into the combustion chamber, with that previously mentioned 2.5 tons/second flow rate. That's quite a powerful pump, even Grady from Practical Engineering would be impressed. But on top of the pressure rise necessary to make the propellants flow into the high pressure combustion chamber, there's an additional large increase in pressure needed to make the propellant flow through those hundreds or thousands of tiny tubes. And the power required to run the pump scales directly with the number and diameter of those little tubes (And the viscosity of the coolant). but what else scales with the number and diameter of tubes? Cooling performance. So more, smaller tubes = better cooling performance, but also more power required to run the pumps. So if a propellant is a more efficient coolant (I.E. better heat capacity, conductivity, lower initial temperature, and higher max temperature before chemical instability), it can keep things cool enough with fewer, larger tubes instead of more, smaller tubes. Meaning that the cooling properties of the propellant directly influence the size of the turbopumps, and the amount of the fuel's chemical energy that needs to be expended in the preburner to run the turbines. You have many levers to pull, and many of them move each time you pull one. And each lever has it's own costs, benefits, and limits.

Aircraft gas turbine engines use some of the same tricks to achieve higher combustion temperatures (and thus fuel economy) and also enable higher compression ratios (and thus better fuel economy again). In the main they coat the blades with ceramic composites to handle higher heat and almost all blades now have active cooling where they have air passages inside them to help cool them (exiting at the blade trailing edge) and holes just aft of the blade leading edge to film cool the outside. This 'cooling air' is drawn from a late stage of compression (thus high enough pressure to go the right way) and itself is already several hundred degrees C. But compared to the 2500C combustion gas... its relatively cold!

Jet turbine maintenance engineer here, we use most of these same methods to prevent aircraft engines eating themselves. Primarily film cooling though. Most engines tap off high pressure bleed air from the final stage of the compressor (which is already at around 300°c or more to cool the hot parts of the engines. Effectively in a turbine engine the combustion gases will NEVER actually contact any of the metal parts as they'd simply burn through it in seconds.

Most impressive one being that the turbine blades are grown from a single crystal of titanium, are hollow to utilise the regenerative cooling via channels inside and then vent those hot gasses via tiny holes in the surface to maintain a film of gas in between the blade itself and the combustion gases, all while spinning hundreds of times a second

Fully burning RP1 makes more CO2 which has a high molecular weight, 44. That gets you a higher exhaust velocity and a higher isp.

Heatsink chambers are useful for experimental engines where one is trying to determine, for instance, the shortest chamber that can support complete combustion. That was the rationale for the various "trombone" engines we ran at XCOR, one of the cases where I actually did some rocket science rather than just engineering.

The best material for a heatsink is usually copper, for its combination of high thermal conductivity, ease of fabrication, and cost.

Using low thermal conductivity materials in a regen or heatsink engine is a bad idea, even though such metals may have higher melting point, they will quickly reach that melting point where a lower melting but higher conductivity engine can be kept cool.

Great video and amazing visuals! Although the parts about soot being dark because it hasn't had time to react with O2 is not quite right. The major reason has to do with incandescence (i.e. black body radiation) of the particles present in the exhaust. This is the same mechanism that causes the nozzles of say MVAC to glow bright red.

The reason there is a difference between the Space Shuttle Engines and the Delta IV engines is because of the absence of soot in the Space Shuttle engine exhaust. When there is no soot, how the exhaust looks is dominated by electron transitions emitting photons at very specific wavelengths. For the Delta IV engines, the ablative coating being shot out the engine is achieving high enough temperatures to become incandescent. This is similar to why Bunsen burner flames are bright blue (pre mixed flames emitting photons through electron transitions) versus why candle flames are reddish (soot particles at the diffusion flame front become hot and glow incandescently).

The reason the turbine exhaust on Merlin engines is dark has more to do with the soot density and relatively low temperature of the exhaust than anything else. Soot density is also related to how complicated the fuel molecule is. Longer chain hydrocarbon fuels such as RP1 will generate a lot of soot and so the exhaust will glow bright whitish-red. Simpler fuels like Methane have a much lower soot density and so do not burn as brightly. In the case of Raptor where they're operating pretty close to stoichiometric, very little soot is generated and the dominating emission is then again by electron transitions.

In the V-2 rocket, Methane and Liquid Oxygen, from separate tanks, were force-fed together into the combustion chamber via 2 gas-powered turbines (which itself was powered by the reaction of two other expanding-chemicals to turn the turbine blades; the exhaust of which separately vented out the side of the rocket). Tons of heavy thrust was required to move a rocket that itself weighed several tons due to the Methane and Liquid Oxygen it carried , as well as, the gyroscopes, turbines, wiring systems, and payload of explosives. It also used fuel-film-coating to cover the inner walls of the combustion chamber.

Top notch content, as the norm for your material.
A couple of comments at two points:
You mention "efficiency" WRT running fuel rich in most cases. Not states is this raises ISP - I'm sure that's what you meant. I think this is something that many miss; often off stoichiometric often results in a higher ISP. Rich is less "efficient" on the thermal efficiency side, but where all propellant comes from the tanks, the ISP is the most important. With hydrocarbon fuels, running rich is definitely more efficient when measuring ISP. Complete combustion of the carbon in the fuel results in CO2, running rich makes lots of CO. CO2 is much more dense, having a molar mass of 44 vs 28 for CO. For the same mass flow, CO accelerates to a much higher velocity than CO2 does. Running CO over CO2 results in a lower temperature though, so the peak efficiency is somewhere around 50/50 CO2/CO.
On regenerative cooling, closed cycles can also recover the heat and turn it into pump energy in addition to expander cycles. If the same propellant that is used for cooling is used as the pre-burner majority fuel, then the heat recovered in the regenerative loop is added to the turbine input. In Raptor the methane is boiled and warmed before it enters the pre-burner and takes less oxidizer there to create the same level of turbine power. The RS-25 takes this to the extreme where the low pressure turbo-pump is expander driven.

What I've always found interesting is how SIMPLE heavy-lift, orbital-class rocketry would be if we had materials that could withstand enormous amounts of heat. Like: think about all the complex plumbing that could be eliminated from rocket engines, the heat shields that wouldn't be needed, the complicated air-braking strategies, etc. Hypothetically, if someday somebody were to invent a material that is reasonably easy to work with, reasonably affordable, has good structural properties, and is immune to enormous amounts of heat, rocket design could be like an order of magnitude simpler!
